body: @richdougherty Looks like this was caused by #5266

Would you mind giving headers for a working and non-working requests? I can reproduce if I set headers to:

```
X-Forwarded-For: ::1
```

I think the reason is that we are now actually parsing the `X-Forwarded-For` header value. Maybe we need to make the parsing lazy, so we only actually parse if we need to check that an address is a trusted proxy. The reason the parsing is failing is that we are expecting IPv6 addresses to follow the format in RFC7239, i.e. `[::1]` not `::1`.

You may be able to fix this by changing your settings to:

```
proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $remote_addr;
```

This will tell Play that you forwarded the connection for the given `$remote_addr` and Play will use that value as the request's `remoteAddress` property. It will also remove the troublesome `::1` entry from the `X-Forwarded-For` header. Play ignores the `X-Real-IP` header so there's no point setting it.
I think we should only parse this header if we need to check trusted proxies. I'm sure there are a lot of people with this nginx configuration. At most we should log a warning here.

>  I'm sure there are a lot of people with this nginx configuration. At most we should log a warning here.

Unfortunately, yes - especially those who are [moving from Apache](https://www.nginx.com/resources/wiki/start/topics/examples/likeapache/).

> The reason the parsing is failing is that we are expecting IPv6 addresses to follow the format in RFC7239 i.e. [::1] not ::1.

Hm ... I've found something in the RFC which mentions that this format [is not always expectable](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7239#section-7.4):

> Note that IPv6 addresses may not be quoted in X-Forwarded-For and may not be enclosed by square brackets, but they  are quoted and enclosed in square brackets in "Forwarded".

I.e. it's valid to not use brackets within the X-Forwarded-For header - the brackets are only required in the "Forwarded" format.

> You may be able to fix this by changing your settings to: [...]

This does not work either - it fails with the same exception.

> Would you mind giving headers for a working and non-working requests? [...]

(â‚¬dit: Accidentally posted the wrong list of headers before ... sorry!)
Here we go (extracted from Wireshark, body skipped):

From a working request (POST via XHR):

```
POST /query?clientId=780e176a-ffff-4531-adfe-c1a68c3e70d9 HTTP/1.0
X-Real-IP: ::1
X-Forwarded-For: ::1
Host: localhost:9000
Connection: close
Content-Length: 347
Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01
Origin: http://localhost:9000
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Ubuntu Chromium/45.0.2454.101 Chrome/45.0.2454.101 Safari/537.36
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
Referer: http://localhost:9000/
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept-Language: de-DE,de;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.6,en;q=0.4
Cookie: PLAY_SESSION=3648d0e3ce9f21e56f0e727a59046a93c7e8ac56-clientId=780e176a-ffff-4531-adfe-c1a68c3e70d9
DNT: 1
```

From a non-working request (form submission):

```
POST /login HTTP/1.0
X-Real-IP: ::1
X-Forwarded-For: ::1
Host: localhost:9000
Connection: close
Content-Length: 73
Cache-Control: max-age=0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8
Origin: http://localhost:9000
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Ubuntu Chromium/45.0.2454.101 Chrome/45.0.2454.101 Safari/537.36
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Referer: http://localhost:9000/
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept-Language: de-DE,de;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.6,en;q=0.4
Cookie: PLAY_SESSION=3648d0e3ce9f21e56f0e727a59046a93c7e8ac56-clientId=780e176a-ffff-4531-adfe-c1a68c3e70d9
DNT: 1
```

I'll change the code to be more lazy and forgiving and to log warnings instead of throw errors.

Thanks for the headers. From the exception message I assume both of these requests come via a proxy on 127.0.0.1 connecting via HTTP. I also assume you're using [default settings for trusted proxies](https://www.playframework.com/documentation/2.4.x/HTTPServer#Configure-trusted-proxies), not doing anything special.

I think the reason it works for one request, but fails for another, is that the failing request will be trying to read the request's `remoteAddress` or `secure` flag, whereas the working request won't be accessing these values. The header parsing is lazy so it should only occur when `remoteAddress` or `secure` is accessed. Can you look at the stack trace and check that the code accessing `remoteAddress` and `secure` is your application code and not something that Play is doing automatically. If you can verify this then that will explain why one request is working and the other request is failing. If you're not sure, maybe you can paste more of the stack trace here.

> I assume both of these requests come via a proxy on 127.0.0.1 connecting via HTTP. I also assume you're using default settings for trusted proxies, not doing anything special.

Both is correct - the nginx proxy in front only takes care of serving several static assets, especially the versioned one within the production environment. For development, this setup would not be required, but it's useful to mirror the production environment's behavior to detect things like this issue before they even get a chance to cause problems there.

> Can you look at the stack trace [...]

I fear that what I've posted already _is_ the whole stacktrace that occurs in the logs.

> [...] and check that the code accessing `remoteAddress` and `secure` is your application code and not something that Play is doing automatically [...]

It seems that our code causes this -  `request.remoteAddress` get accessed on the login hook, but not on the hook that deals with the XHRs. This access is not that relevant and might be removed (and the login works if I do so, of course). However, we've got other hooks accessing the remote address field for performing some checks on it, and I must not change these.

Thanks for confirming both of those points.

I think you can get more stack trace by adjusting your logback settings: https://www.playframework.com/documentation/2.4.x/SettingsLogger#Default-configuration.

issue.title: More fixes to forward header parsing

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Fixes #5299.

Parsing for `Forward` and `X-Forwarded-*` headers no longer throws exceptions if an invalid header is found. Now a debug log message is thrown instead. This reverses the stricter errors introduced in #5266.

Additional changes were made:
- Don't bother parsing the supplied IP address headers if we don't trust the connection that supplied it.
- Support values in Forward headers surrounded with double quotes. This is needed to support IPv6.
- Support IPv6 values in X-Forwarded-For headers even when they don't have surrounding square brackets. This format is commonly supplied by proxies.

body: I've submitted a fix to this issue now, you may want to review it: #5306.
